title: What Is Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder (DSED)?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: ‌Disinhibited social engagement disorder (DSED) is an attachment disorder that happens in young children, causing them to easily approach and talk to strangers. They are also comfortable seeking comfort from unfamiliar people.
Here is all you need to know about DSED, from causes to treatments, and more.

Disinhibited social engagement disorder is an attachment disorder where children feel comfortable approaching and interacting with strangers. Symptoms usually appear by the age of 9 months. Treatment options include counseling and certain therapies, and medications for co-occurring conditions like ADHD. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)

content_blocks.text: ‌Disinhibited social engagement disorder (DSED) is an attachment disorder that happens in young children, causing them to easily approach and talk to strangers. They are also comfortable seeking comfort from unfamiliar people.
Here is all you need to know about DSED, from causes to treatments, and more.

Disinhibited social engagement disorder is an attachment disorder where children feel comfortable approaching and interacting with strangers. Symptoms usually appear by the age of 9 months. Treatment options include counseling and certain therapies, and medications for co-occurring conditions like ADHD. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)

sections.heading: Understanding Attachment Disorders
content: ‌Attachment disorders are common in children who are abandoned or experience trauma at a young age, such as having negative experiences or not getting enough care from their parents or guardians. This can prevent a child from forming meaningful or close bonds with people.
Attachment disorders can be of two types based on the affected child's behavior:

Reactive attachment disorder (RAD). Children with RAD find it difficult to have an emotional attachment to their parents or guardians and other people. These children fear interactions with others and have trouble managing or expressing their feelings.‌

DSED. Unlike children with RAD, those with DSED appear to be extremely friendly and outgoing. They exhibit socially disinhibited behavior. This means they are impulsive and can easily talk to unknown people and random strangers. However, they may have trouble forming stable or meaningful bonds with others.
Children with attachment disorders require proper treatment and care. If left untreated, attachment disorders can result in mental disorders at later stages in life.

Reactive attachment disorder (RAD). Children with RAD find it difficult to have an emotional attachment to their parents or guardians and other people. These children fear interactions with others and have trouble managing or expressing their feelings.‌

DSED. Unlike children with RAD, those with DSED appear to be extremely friendly and outgoing. They exhibit socially disinhibited behavior. This means they are impulsive and can easily talk to unknown people and random strangers. However, they may have trouble forming stable or meaningful bonds with others.
Children with attachment disorders require proper treatment and care. If left untreated, attachment disorders can result in mental disorders at later stages in life.

sections.heading: What Are the Causes of Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder?
content: ‌DSED can occur in children for the following reasons:‌
‌These factors can make it difficult for children to connect more deeply with other people. It can also make them behave in a seemingly carefree or overly friendly manner.
bullets: Absence of a caregiver or parent in the first few years of childhood
Lack of love, care, or emotional support while growing up
Neglect or abandonment by caregivers
Lack of a constant caregiver or repeated changing of caregivers
Negative experiences such as childhood trauma or sexual abuse
Growing up in foster care or orphanages

content_blocks.text: ‌DSED can occur in children for the following reasons:‌
associated_bullets: Absence of a caregiver or parent in the first few years of childhood
Lack of love, care, or emotional support while growing up
Neglect or abandonment by caregivers
Lack of a constant caregiver or repeated changing of caregivers
Negative experiences such as childhood trauma or sexual abuse
Growing up in foster care or orphanages

content_blocks.text: ‌These factors can make it difficult for children to connect more deeply with other people. It can also make them behave in a seemingly carefree or overly friendly manner.

sections.heading: What Are the Symptoms of Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder (DSED)?
content: ‌Children as young as 9 months old can develop signs of DSED. If a child shows even two of the following symptoms, they may have DSED:‌
Children with DSED have severe difficulty in forming warm, affectionate, or close bonds with other children or adults. If DSED goes undiagnosed, it can cause the following issues later in life:‌
bullets: They are not shy or scared but excited when they meet strangers or unknown people.
‌They are extremely friendly, chatty, or physically close with strangers.
‌They behave in a socially unacceptable manner according to social norms.
‌They leave a safe space and go away with a stranger.
‌They don't ask their caregiver or hesitate before going away with a stranger.
‌They are impulsive and socially disinhibited.
‌They have not been cared for adequately or have a history of trauma or abuse.
Emerging personality disorders like borderline personality disorder
‌Behavioral disorders like attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Drug addiction and substance abuse

content_blocks.text: ‌Children as young as 9 months old can develop signs of DSED. If a child shows even two of the following symptoms, they may have DSED:‌
associated_bullets: They are not shy or scared but excited when they meet strangers or unknown people.
‌They are extremely friendly, chatty, or physically close with strangers.
‌They behave in a socially unacceptable manner according to social norms.
‌They leave a safe space and go away with a stranger.
‌They don't ask their caregiver or hesitate before going away with a stranger.
‌They are impulsive and socially disinhibited.
‌They have not been cared for adequately or have a history of trauma or abuse.

associated_bullets: Emerging personality disorders like borderline personality disorder
‌Behavioral disorders like attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Drug addiction and substance abuse

sections.heading: What Are The Risks of Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder (DSED)?
content: Certain care settings and conditions can put a child at risk of developing DSED. These include:

DSED can affect your child's ability to form healthy relationships with other children and adults, and their ability to be socially aware. Children with DSED are also at risk of peer conflict and mistreatment.
bullets: Being abandoned, neglected, restricted, or deprived
Many changes in primary caregivers, which don't allow for making connections
Being raised in different centers, such as orphanages or foster care, which may not allow for attachments

content_blocks.text: Certain care settings and conditions can put a child at risk of developing DSED. These include:
associated_bullets: Being abandoned, neglected, restricted, or deprived
Many changes in primary caregivers, which don't allow for making connections
Being raised in different centers, such as orphanages or foster care, which may not allow for attachments

content_blocks.text: DSED can affect your child's ability to form healthy relationships with other children and adults, and their ability to be socially aware. Children with DSED are also at risk of peer conflict and mistreatment.

sections.heading: How Is Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder(DSED) Diagnosed?
content: Remember that not all children who are friendly with strangers have DSED. Your child may be naturally outgoing and talkative with others. However, they will still seek your approval for safety at all times.
A child with DSED is usually detached and doesn't seek their caregiver's approval. If your child is not at all afraid of leaving with strangers, you may want to take them to a doctor. ‌

content_blocks.text: Remember that not all children who are friendly with strangers have DSED. Your child may be naturally outgoing and talkative with others. However, they will still seek your approval for safety at all times.
A child with DSED is usually detached and doesn't seek their caregiver's approval. If your child is not at all afraid of leaving with strangers, you may want to take them to a doctor. ‌

content: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM)-5 criteria for disinhibited social engagement disorder include repeated behavior of a child going up to and interacting with an adult stranger, and also showing at least two of the following:
The criteria for DSED diagnosis also include evidence of extreme neglect or lack of care, shown by at least one of the following:
If these conditions are present for more than 12 months, the DSED is considered to be persistent. If symptoms are continuously seen at a higher level, the condition is considered to be severe.
bullets: reduced or no resistance to approach an unfamiliar adult
less or no resistance to go off with an unfamiliar adult
reduced or absent need for reassurance from caregiver when stepping away, even in settings that are new
greater physical or verbal behavior than typical within age range
repeated lack of emotional needs being met
consistent changes in primary caregivers
upbringing in abnormal settings that limit ability for attachment

content_blocks.text: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM)-5 criteria for disinhibited social engagement disorder include repeated behavior of a child going up to and interacting with an adult stranger, and also showing at least two of the following:
associated_bullets: reduced or no resistance to approach an unfamiliar adult
less or no resistance to go off with an unfamiliar adult
reduced or absent need for reassurance from caregiver when stepping away, even in settings that are new
greater physical or verbal behavior than typical within age range

content_blocks.text: The criteria for DSED diagnosis also include evidence of extreme neglect or lack of care, shown by at least one of the following:
associated_bullets: repeated lack of emotional needs being met
consistent changes in primary caregivers
upbringing in abnormal settings that limit ability for attachment

content_blocks.text: If these conditions are present for more than 12 months, the DSED is considered to be persistent. If symptoms are continuously seen at a higher level, the condition is considered to be severe.

sections.heading: At what age is DSED diagnosed?
content: A pediatrician or therapist can diagnose DSED. They observe your child and conduct mental health tests . This helps them understand your child’s history, emotions, mental state, and social behavior.
Children with DSED usually show symptoms of the condition by at least 9 months of age.

sections.heading: What Are the Treatments for Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder?
content: ‌If diagnosed with DSED, your child will be given all the care they need through a specific treatment plan. This will help your child overcome negative experiences and grow up to form meaningful relationships with you and others.
‌DSED treatment involves the entire family so that the child can bond with their caregivers. Treatment can include the following therapies, depending on the child's age:‌

The therapist also helps parents interact with their children to care for and support them, making their bond stronger. This can help children feel stable, safe, and loved so that they recover sooner.
bullets: Talk therapy
Play therapy with toys and games
Art therapy

content_blocks.text: ‌If diagnosed with DSED, your child will be given all the care they need through a specific treatment plan. This will help your child overcome negative experiences and grow up to form meaningful relationships with you and others.
‌DSED treatment involves the entire family so that the child can bond with their caregivers. Treatment can include the following therapies, depending on the child's age:‌
associated_bullets: Talk therapy
Play therapy with toys and games
Art therapy

content_blocks.text: The therapist also helps parents interact with their children to care for and support them, making their bond stronger. This can help children feel stable, safe, and loved so that they recover sooner.

sections.heading: How Do You Take Care of a Child With Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder?
content: ‌DSED can be a serious problem if it remains untreated. Although therapy can take time, it is the most effective treatment for DSED. If you are a caregiver, ensure that you give your child all the love, care, and emotional support they need.
Being present for your child, talking with them, and setting clear rules to keep them safe are important, too. Some tips include:
bullets: Being a source of comfort and structure
Teaching normal social behaviors and boundaries
Taking steps to ensure their safety, such as teaching them their telephone number and address, or dressing them in bright clothes
Engaging in stress-relieving activities for yourself

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Disinhibited social engagement disorder is an attachment disorder where children feel unusually comfortable approaching and interacting with strangers. Symptoms usually appear by the age of 9 months. Treatment options include counseling, certain therapies, and medications for co-occurring conditions such as ADHD.

Symptoms usually appear by the age of 9 months. Treatment options include counseling, certain therapies, and medications for co-occurring conditions such as ADHD.

sections.heading: FAQs About Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder
What does DSED look like in adults?
content: While both conditions are attachment disorders, children with DSED are very affectionate with others, and those with RAD have trouble forming an emotional attachment with others and appear withdrawn.
Symptoms of DSED that continue into adulthood include hyperactivity and lack of focus.

There aren't specific medications for DSED, but your doctor may prescribe certain medications for co-occurring conditions. These may include stimulants for ADHD or SSRIs for mood and anxiety disorders.

meta_description: Disinhibited social engagement disorder is an attachment disorder seen in young children. Learn about what causes it, what to expect, and more.
